Transparent Interconnection of Lots of Links (TRILL):
Using Data Labels for Tree Selection for Multi-Destination Data
Abstract
contents.ja: 抽象

contents.text: TRILL (Transparent Interconnection of Lots of Links) uses distribution trees to deliver multi-destination frames. Multiple trees can be used by an ingress Routing Bridge (RBridge) for flows, regardless of the VLAN, Fine-Grained Label (FGL), and/or multicast group of the flow. Different ingress RBridges may choose different distribution trees for TRILL Data packets in the same VLAN, FGL, and/or multicast group. To avoid unnecessary link utilization, distribution trees should be pruned based on one or more of the following: VLAN, FGL, or multicast destination address. If any VLAN, FGL, or multicast group can be sent on any tree, for typical fast-path hardware, the amount of pruning information is multiplied by the number of trees, but there is limited hardware capacity for such pruning information.
contents.ja: TRILL（リンクの多くの透明相互接続）が同報フレームを配信する配信ツリーを使用します。複数のツリーに関係なくVLANの、ファイングレインラベル（FGL）、フローの入口ルーティングブリッジ（RBridge）によって使用される、および/またはフローのマルチキャストグループことができます。異なる入口RBridgesは同じVLAN、FGL、及び/又はマルチキャストグループにTRILLデータパケットに対して異なる配信ツリーを選択することができます。 VLAN、FGL、またはマルチキャストの宛先アドレス：不要なリンク利用を避けるために、分散ツリーは、次の一つ以上に基づいて剪定する必要があります。任意のVLAN、FGL、またはマルチキャストグループは、任意のツリー上で送信することができる場合、典型的なファストパスハードウェアのために、プルーニング情報の量は、木の数を乗じ、そのようなプルーニング情報の限られたハードウェア能力があるれています。

contents.text: This document specifies an optional facility to restrict the TRILL Data packets sent on particular distribution trees by VLAN, FGL, and/or multicast groups, thus reducing the total amount of pruning information so that it can more easily be accommodated by fast-path hardware.

contents.ja: 1.1。背景説明

contents.text: One or more distribution trees, identified by their root nicknames, are used to distribute multi-destination data in a (Transparent Interconnection of Lots of Links) (TRILL) campus [RFC6325]. The Routing Bridge (RBridge) having the highest tree root priority announces the total number of trees that should be computed for the campus. It may also specify the list of trees that RBridges need to compute using the Tree Identifiers (TREE-RT-IDs) sub-TLV [RFC7176]. Every RBridge can specify the trees it will use for multi-destination TRILL Data packets it originates in the Trees Used Identifiers (TREE-USE-IDs) sub-TLV [RFC7176], and the VLANs or Fine-Grained Labels (FGLs) [RFC7172] it is interested in are specified in Interested VLANs and/or Interested Labels sub-TLVs [RFC7176]. It is suggested that by default the ingress RBridge uses the distribution tree whose root is the closest [RFC6325]. The TREE-USE-IDs sub-TLV is used to build the RPF (Reverse Path Forwarding) check table that is used for RPF checking. Interested VLANs and Interested Labels sub-TLVs are used for distribution tree pruning, and the multi-destination forwarding table with pruning information is built based on that RPF check table. To reduce unnecessary link loads, each distribution tree should be pruned per VLAN/FGL, eliminating branches that have no potential receivers downstream as specified in [RFC6325]. Further pruning based on Layer 2 or Layer 3 multicast addresses is also possible.

With the increasing demand to use TRILL in data center networks, there are some features we can explore for multi-destination frames in the data center use case. An ingress RBridge has two options to select the tree root for multi-destination frames: choose one and only one as the distribution tree root, or use an ECMP-like algorithm to balance the traffic among the multiple trees whose roots are at the same distance from the RBridge.

contents.text: For any RBridge RBn, for each VLAN x, if RBn is in a distribution tree t used by traffic in VLAN x, there will be an entry of (t, x, port list) in the multicast forwarding table on RBn. Typically, each entry contains a distinct combination of (tree nickname, VLAN) as the lookup key. If there are n such trees and m such VLANs, the multicast forwarding table size on RBn is n*m entries. If an FGL is used [RFC7172] and/or finer pruning is used (for example, VLAN + multicast group address is used for pruning), the value of m increases. In the larger-scale data center, more trees would be necessary for purposes of better load-balancing; this results in an increased value for n. In either case, the number of table entries (i.e., n*m) will increase dramatically.

But few, if any, fast-path implementations provide such logic.

contents.text: A straightforward way to alleviate the problem of limited table entries is not to prune the distribution tree. However, this can only be used in restricted scenarios, for the following reasons:
contents.ja: 限られたテーブルエントリの問題を軽減するための簡単な方法は、配信ツリーを剪定することではありません。しかし、これが唯一の次のような理由から、制限されたシナリオで使用することができます。

contents.text: - Not pruning wastes bandwidth for multi-destination packets. There is normally broadcast traffic, like ARP and unknown unicast, that can be pruned on a VLAN (or FGL) so that it is not sent down branches of a distribution tree where it is not needed. In addition, if there is a lot of Layer 3 multicast traffic, no pruning may result in a worst-case scenario where that user data is unnecessarily flooded all over the campus. The volume of flooded data could be very large if certain applications such as IPTV are supported. More precise pruning, such as pruning based on multicast groups, may be desirable in this case.
contents.ja: - マルチ先パケットの廃棄物の帯域幅を剪定されていません。通常、それはそれが必要とされていないディストリビューションツリーの枝を下に送信されないように、VLAN（またはFGL）に剪定することができARPおよび未知のユニキャスト、同様に、トラフィックが放送されています。レイヤ3マルチキャストトラフィックが多い場合にはまた、何の剪定は、そのユーザデータが不必要に全てのキャンパス上でフラッディングされる最悪のシナリオではなくなることがあります。例えばIPTVのような特定のアプリケーションがサポートされている場合に浸水データの量が非常に大きくなり得ます。より正確な剪定、マルチキャストグループに基づくようなプルーニングは、この場合に望ましいかもしれません。

contents.text: - Not pruning is only useful at pure transit nodes. Edge nodes always need to maintain the multicast forwarding table with the key of (tree nickname + VLAN (or FGL)), since the edge node needs to decide whether and how to replicate the frame to local access ports. It is likely that edge nodes are relatively low-end switches with a smaller shared table size, say 4K, available.

If there are multiple tree nicknames announced in a TREE-VLANs APPsub-TLV for VLAN x, the ingress RBridge chooses one of them if it supports this feature. For example, the ingress RBridge may choose the closest (minimum-cost) root among them. How to make such a choice is out of scope for this document. It may be desirable to have some fixed algorithm to make sure that all ingress RBridges choose the same tree for VLAN x in this case. Any single Data Label that the ingress RBridge is interested in should be related to only one tree ID in a TREE-VLAN-USE APPsub-TLV to minimize the multicast forwarding table size on other RBridges, but as long as the Data Label is related to less than all the trees being calculated, it will reduce the burden on the forwarding table size.

contents.text: 3.4. Failure Handling
contents.ja: 3.4。障害処理

contents.text: This section discusses failure scenarios for a distribution tree root for the case where that tree root is not the highest-priority root and the case where it is the highest-priority root. This section also discusses some other transient error conditions.
contents.ja: このセクションでは、そのツリーのルートは、それが最優先のルートで最も優先順位の高いルートとそうではない場合の配信ツリールートの故障シナリオについて説明します。このセクションでは、他のいくつかの一時的なエラー条件について説明します。

contents.text: Failure of a tree root that is not the highest-priority tree root: It is the responsibility of the highest-priority tree root to inform other RBridges of any change in the allowed tree-VLAN correspondence. When the highest-priority tree root learns that the root of tree t has failed, it should reassign the VLANs allowed on tree t to other trees or to a tree replacing the failed one.
contents.ja: 最優先のツリーのルートではありませんツリーのルートの失敗：許さツリーVLAN対応の変化の他のRBridgesを知らせるために、最も優先度の高いツリーのルートの責任です。最優先のツリーのルートは、ツリーTのルートが失敗したことを知ったとき、それが失敗したものを交換し、他の樹木や木に木T上で許可されるVLANを割り当て直す必要があります。

contents.text: Failure of the highest-priority tree root: It is suggested that the tree root of second-highest priority be pre-configured with the proper knowledge of the tree-VLAN correspondence allowed when the highest-priority tree root fails. The information announced by the RBridge that has the second-highest priority to be a tree root would be in the link state of all RBridges but would not take effect unless the RBridge noticed the failure of the highest-priority tree root. When the highest-priority tree root fails, the tree root that formerly had second-highest priority will become the highest-priority tree root of the campus. When an RBridge notices the failure of the original highest-priority tree root, it can immediately use the stored information announced by the tree root that originally had second-highest priority. It is suggested that the tree-VLAN correspondence information be pre-configured on the tree root of second-highest priority to be the same as that on the highest-priority tree root for the trees other than the highest-priority tree itself. This can minimize the change to multicast forwarding tables in the case of highest-priority tree root failure. For a large campus, it may make sense to pre-configure this information in a similar way on the third-priority, fourth-priority, or even lower-priority tree root RBridges.

contents.ja: 4.下位互換性
